NDResourceFork

A class to access manipulate resource forks from Cocoa.

Superclass: NSObject
Declared In: NDResourceFork

Discussion

NDResourceFork allows your cocoa application create, delete, open, read, modify, and write resources; get information about them. A resource is data of any kind stored in a defined format in a file's resource fork. On intialization, NDResourceFork open the resource fork and then closes the resource for when it is deallocated.


Methods

-addData:type:Id:name:

Adds a resource to the receivers resource file.

-addData:type:name:

addData:type:Id:name:

Adds a resource to the receivers resource file. 

- (BOOL)addData:(NSData *)data type:(ResType)type Id:(ResID)ID 
        name:(NSString *)name;
Parameters
data

An NSData object containing the data to be added as a resource to the receivers resource file.

type

The resource type of the resource to be added.

ID

The resource ID of the resource to be added.

name

The name of the resource to be added.

Return Value

Returns YES if the resource was successfully added, otherwise it returns NO.

Discussion

addData:type:name: doesn't verify whether the resource ID you pass in the parameter ID is already assigned to another resource of the same type. You should use the methods addData:type:name: or dataForType:named: to get a unique resource ID when adding a resource . addData:type:Id:named: returns YES on success

addData:type:name:

Adds a resource to the receivers resource file. 

- (BOOL)addData:(NSData *)data type:(ResType)type name:(NSString *)name;
Parameters
data

An NSData object containing the data to be added as a resource to the receivers resource file.

type

The resource type of the resource to be added.

name

The name of the resource to be added.

Return Value

Returns YES if the resource was successfully added, otherwise it returns NO.

Discussion

addData:type:name: uses an unique resource ID when adding a resource . addData:type:Id:named: returns YES on success

closeFile

- (void)closeFile;

dataForEntireResourceFork

Reads the receivers entire resource data. 

- (NSData *)dataForEntireResourceFork;
Return Value

A NSData object containing the resources data.

Discussion

dataForEntireResourceFork returns a NSData object that contains the entire contents of the resource fork. dataForEntireResourceFork and it's conpanion method writeEntireResourceFork can be used for duplicating the resource fork for on file to the resource fork of another. dataForEntireResourceFork can also be used to convert a resource stored in a files resource fork into a resource stored in a data fork, simple by using the NSData methods writeToFile:atomically: or writeToURL:atomically:.

dataForType:Id:

Gets resource data for a resource in the receivers resource file. 

- (NSData *)dataForType:(ResType)type Id:(ResID)ID;
Parameters
type

The resource type of the resource which you wish to retrieve data.

ID

An integer that uniquely identifies the resource which you wish to retrieve data.

Return Value

Returns an NSData object if successful otherwise returns nil.

Discussion

dataForType:Id: searches the receivers resource file's resource map in memory for the specified resource.

dataForType:named:

Gets resource data for a resource in the receivers resource file. 

- (NSData *)dataForType:(ResType)type named:(NSString *)name;
Parameters
type

The resource type of the resource which you wish to retrieve data.

name

A name that uniquely identifies the resource which you wish to retrieve data. Strings passed in this parameter are case-sensitive.

Return Value

Returns an NSData object if successful otherwise returns nil.

Discussion

dataForType:Id: searches the receivers resource file's resource map in memory for the specified resource.

everyResourceType

Gets every resource type available in the receivers resource file. 

- (NSArray *)everyResourceType;
Return Value

A NSArray of NSNumbers containing ResTypes.

Discussion

everyResourceType returns an NSArray of NSNumbers each containing a unsigned long or ResTypes.

everyResourceType

Gets every resource type available in the receivers resource file. 

- (NSArray *)everyResourceType;
Return Value

A NSArray of NSNumbers containing ResTypes.

Discussion

everyResourceType returns an NSArray of NSNumbers each containing a unsigned long or ResTypes.

getAttributeFlags:forResourceType:Id:

Gets a resource's attributes. 

- (BOOL)getAttributeFlags:(ResAttributes*)attributes 
        forResourceType:(ResType)type Id:(ResID)ID;
Parameters
attributes

A pointer to an ResAttributes that on return contains the resources attributes, if the returned value is YES.

type

The resource type of the resource for which you wish to retrieve the attributes.

ID

An integer that uniquely identifies the resource for which you wish to retrieve the attributes.

Return Value

A YES if retrieval was successful.

Discussion

Returns the attributes for a resource in a pointer to a ResAttributes and returns YES if retrieval of the attributes is succeeded. If getAttributeFlags:forResourceType:Id: returns NO then the value returned through the pointer attributes is garabage.

getId:ofResourceType:named:

Gets a named resource's resource id. 

- (BOOL)getId:(ResID *)ID ofResourceType:(ResType)type named:(NSString *)name;
Parameters
ID

A pointer to an ResID that on return contains the resources id, if the returned value is YES.

type

The resource type of the resource for which you wish to retrieve the id.

name

The resource name of the resource for which you wish to retrieve the id.

Return Value

A YES if retrieval was successful.

Discussion

Returns a resources id in a pointer to a ResID and returns YES if retrieval of the id is succeeded. If getId:ofResourceType:named: returns NO then the value returned through the pointer ID is garabage.

initForPermission:atPath:

Initalises a NDResourceFork. 

- (id)initForPermission:(char)permission atPath:(NSString *)path;
Parameters
permission

read/write permissions for the opened resource fork.

path

A path specifying the name and location of the file whose resource fork is to be opened.

Return Value

An initialized NDResourceFork for an opened resource fork, returns nil if the resource fork could not be opened or initalization failed.

Discussion

Intializes the receiver and opens a resource fork for reading and/or writting using the path. If write permission is specified, then an empty resource fork created before hand if it does not already exists. The receivers resource fork is closed when the receiver is deallocated. Possible permission values are as follows;

fsCurPerm Requests whatever permissions are currently allowed. If write access in unavailable (because the file is locked or the file is already open with write permission), then read permission is granted. Otherwise read/write permission is granted.
fsRdPerm Requests permission to read the file.
fsWrPerm Requests permission to write to the file. If write permission is granted, no other access paths are granted write permission. Note, however, that the File Manager does not support write-only access to a file. Thus, fsWrPerm is synonymous with fsRdWrPerm .
fsRdWrPerm Requests exclusive read and write permission. If exclusive read/ write permission is granted, no other users are granted permission to write to the file. Other users may, however, be granted permission to read the file.
fsRdWrShPerm Requests shared read and write permission. Shared read/ write permission allows mutliple access paths for reading and writing. This is safe only if there is some way of locking portions of the file before writing to them. Use the functions PBLockRangeSync and PBUnlockRangeSync to lock and unlock ranges of bytes within a file. On Mac OS 8 and 9, these functions are supported only on remotely mounted volumes, or on local volumes that are shareable on the network. You should check that range locking is available before requesting shared read/ write permission. On Mac OS X, range locking is available on all volumes.
fsRdDenyPerm Requests that any other paths be prevented from having read access. A path cannot be opened if you request read permission (with the fsRdPerm constant) but some other path has requested deny-read access. Similarly, the path cannot be opened if you request deny-read permission, but some other path already has read access. This constant is used with the PBHOpenDenySync and PBHOpenRFDenySync functions.
fsWrDenyPerm Requests that any other paths be prevented from having write access. A path cannot be opened if you request write permission (with the fsWrPerm constant) but some other path has requested deny-write access. Similarly, the path cannot be opened if you request deny-write permission, but some other path already has write access. This constant is used with the PBHOpenDenySync and PBHOpenRFDenySync functions.

initForPermission:atURL:

Initalises a NDResourceFork. 

- (id)initForPermission:(char)permission atURL:(NSURL *)URL;
Parameters
permission

read/write permissions for the opened resource fork.

URL

A file url specifying the name and location of the file whose resource fork is to be opened.

Return Value

An initialized NDResourceFork for an opened resource fork, returns nil if the resource fork could not be opened or initalization failed.

Discussion

Intializes the receiver and opens a resource fork for reading and/or writting using the file url. If write permission is specified, then an empty resource fork created before hand if it does not already exists. The receivers resource fork is closed when the receiver is deallocated.Possible permission values are as follows;

fsCurPerm Requests whatever permissions are currently allowed. If write access in unavailable (because the file is locked or the file is already open with write permission), then read permission is granted. Otherwise read/write permission is granted.
fsRdPerm Requests permission to read the file.
fsWrPerm Requests permission to write to the file. If write permission is granted, no other access paths are granted write permission. Note, however, that the File Manager does not support write-only access to a file. Thus, fsWrPerm is synonymous with fsRdWrPerm .
fsRdWrPerm Requests exclusive read and write permission. If exclusive read/ write permission is granted, no other users are granted permission to write to the file. Other users may, however, be granted permission to read the file.
fsRdWrShPerm Requests shared read and write permission. Shared read/ write permission allows mutliple access paths for reading and writing. This is safe only if there is some way of locking portions of the file before writing to them. Use the functions PBLockRangeSync and PBUnlockRangeSync to lock and unlock ranges of bytes within a file. On Mac OS 8 and 9, these functions are supported only on remotely mounted volumes, or on local volumes that are shareable on the network. You should check that range locking is available before requesting shared read/ write permission. On Mac OS X, range locking is available on all volumes.
fsRdDenyPerm Requests that any other paths be prevented from having read access. A path cannot be opened if you request read permission (with the fsRdPerm constant) but some other path has requested deny-read access. Similarly, the path cannot be opened if you request deny-read permission, but some other path already has read access. This constant is used with the PBHOpenDenySync and PBHOpenRFDenySync functions.
fsWrDenyPerm Requests that any other paths be prevented from having write access. A path cannot be opened if you request write permission (with the fsWrPerm constant) but some other path has requested deny-write access. Similarly, the path cannot be opened if you request deny-write permission, but some other path already has write access. This constant is used with the PBHOpenDenySync and PBHOpenRFDenySync functions.

initForReadingAtPath:

Initalises a NDResourceFork. 

- (id)initForReadingAtPath:(NSString *)path;
Parameters
path

A path specifying the name and location of the file whose resource fork is to be opened.

Return Value

An initialized NDResourceFork for an opened resource fork, returns nil if the resource fork could not be opened or initalization failed.

Discussion

Intializes the receiver and opens a resource fork for reading using the path. The receivers resource fork is closed when the receiver is deallocated.

initForReadingAtURL:

Initalises a NDResourceFork. 

- (id)initForReadingAtURL:(NSURL *)URL;
Parameters
URL

A file url specifying the name and location of the file whose resource fork is to be opened. The receivers resource fork is closed when the receiver is deallocated.

Return Value

An initialized NDResourceFork for an opened resource fork, returns nil if the resource fork could not be opened or initalization failed.

Discussion

Intializes the receiver and opens a resource fork for reading using the file url.

initForReadingAtURL:

Initalises a NDResourceFork.

See Also:

initForWritingAtURL:

- (id)initForWritingAtURL:(NSURL *)URL;
Parameters
URL

A file url specifying the name and location of the file whose resource fork is to be opened.

Return Value

An initialized NDResourceFork for an opened resource fork, returns nil if the resource fork could not be opened or initalization failed.

Discussion

Intializes the receiver and opens a resource fork for writting, creating it before hand if it does not already exists, using the file url. The receivers resource fork is closed when the receiver is deallocated.

initForWritingAtPath:

Initalises a NDResourceFork. 

- (id)initForWritingAtPath:(NSString *)path;
Parameters
path

A path specifying the name and location of the file whose resource fork is to be opened.

Return Value

An initialized NDResourceFork for an opened resource fork, returns nil if the resource fork could not be opened or initalization failed.

Discussion

Intializes the receiver and opens a resource fork for writting, creating it before hand if it does not already exists, using the path. The receivers resource fork is closed when the receiver is deallocated.

initForWritingAtURL:

Initalises a NDResourceFork.

See Also:

initForReadingAtURL:

- (id)initForWritingAtURL:(NSURL *)URL;
Parameters
URL

A file url specifying the name and location of the file whose resource fork is to be opened.

Discussion

Intializes the receiver and opens a resource fork for writting, creating it before hand if it does not already exists, using the file url. The receivers resource fork is closed when the receiver is deallocated.

nameOfResourceType:Id:

Gets a resource's resource name. 

- (NSString *)nameOfResourceType:(ResType)type Id:(ResID)ID;
Parameters
type

The resource type of the resource for which you wish to retrieve the name.

ID

An integer that uniquely identifies the resource for which you wish to retrieve the name.

Return Value

An NSString containing the resources name.

Discussion

Returns a resources name as an NSString.

removeType:Id:

Removes a resource's entry from the receivers resource file. 

- (BOOL)removeType:(ResType)type Id:(ResID)ID;
Parameters
type

The resource type of the resource which you wish to remove.

ID

An integer that uniquely identifies the resource which you wish to remove.

Return Value

Returns YES if the resource was successfully removed, otherwise if returns NO.

Discussion

If the resProtected attribute for the resource is set, removeType:Id: does nothing, and returns NO.

resourceForkForReadingAtPath:

Creates and initalises a NDResourceFork. 

+ (id)resourceForkForReadingAtPath:(NSString *)path;
Parameters
path

A path specifying the name and location of the file whose resource fork is to be opened.

Return Value

A NDResourceFork for an opened resource fork, returns nil if the resource fork could not be opened or Create and initalise failed.

Discussion

Creates and intializes a NDResourceFork and opens a resource fork for reading using the path. The receivers resource fork is closed when the receiver is deallocated.

resourceForkForReadingAtURL:

Creates and initalises a NDResourceFork. 

+ (id)resourceForkForReadingAtURL:(NSURL *)URL;
Parameters
URL

A file url specifying the name and location of the file whose resource fork is to be opened.

Return Value

A NDResourceFork for an opened resource fork, returns nil if the resource fork could not be opened or Create and initalise failed.

Discussion

Creates and intializes a NDResourceFork and opens a resource fork for reading using the file url.. The NDResourceFork resource fork is closed when the receiver is deallocated.

resourceForkForWritingAtPath:

Creates and initalises a NDResourceFork. 

+ (id)resourceForkForWritingAtPath:(NSString *)path;
Parameters
path

A path specifying the name and location of the file whose resource fork is to be opened.

Return Value

A NDResourceFork for an opened resource fork, returns nil if the resource fork could not be opened or Create and initalise failed.

Discussion

Creates and intializes a NDResourceForkr and opens a resource fork for writting, creating it before hand if it does not already exists, using the path. The receivers resource fork is closed when the receiver is deallocated.

resourceForkForWritingAtURL:

Creates and initalises a NDResourceFork. 

+ (id)resourceForkForWritingAtURL:(NSURL *)URL;
Parameters
URL

A file url specifying the name and location of the file whose resource fork is to be opened.

Return Value

A NDResourceFork for an opened resource fork, returns nil if the resource fork could not be opened or Create and initalise failed.

Discussion

Creates and intializes a NDResourceFork and opens a resource fork for writting, creating it before hand if it does not already exists, using the file url. The NDResourceFork resource fork is closed when the receiver is deallocated.

resourceTypeEnumerator

Get a enumerator for every resource type. 

- (NSEnumerator *)resourceTypeEnumerator;
Return Value

The NSEnumerator.

Discussion

Returns a NSEnumerator which will return a NSNumber resource type.

setAttributeFlags:forResourceType:Id:

Sets a resource's attributes. 

- (BOOL)setAttributeFlags:(ResAttributes)attributes 
        forResourceType:(ResType)type Id:(ResID)ID;
Parameters
attributes

A ResAttributes that contains the resources attributes to be set.

type

The resource type of the resource for which you wish to set the attributes.

ID

An integer that uniquely identifies the resource for which you wish to set the attributes.

Return Value

A YES if setAttributeFlags:forResourceType:Id: was successful in setting the resources attributes.

Discussion

Set the attributes for a resource in attributes and returns YES if setting of the attributes is succeeded.

writeEntireResourceFork:

Writes complete resource data to the receivers resource fork. 

- (BOOL)writeEntireResourceFork:(NSData *)data;
Parameters
data

The complete resource data in a NSData object.

Return Value

Returns YES if writting was successful, returns NO otherwise.

Discussion

writeEntireResourceFork: writes the data in the NSData object out the the recievers resource fork. writeEntireResourceFork and it's conpanion method dataForEntireResourceFork can be used for duplicating the resource fork for on file to the resource fork of another. writeEntireResourceFork: can also be used to convert a resource stored in a files data fork into a resource stored in a files resource fork, simple by creating the NSData object with the methods dataWithContentsOfFile or dataWithContentsOfURL:.
